channel.title: Newest Python PEPs
channel.description: Newest Python Enhancement Proposals (PEPs): Information on new language features and some meta-information like release procedure and schedules.

item.title: PEP 810: Explicit lazy imports
item.description: This PEP introduces syntax for lazy imports as an explicit language feature:
item.author: Pablo Galindo (pablogsal@python.org), Germán Méndez Bravo (german.mb@gmail.com), Thomas Wouters (thomas@python.org), Dino Viehland (dinoviehland@gmail.com), Brittany Reynoso (brittanyrey@gmail.com), Noah Kim (noahbkim@gmail.com), Tim Stumbaugh (me@tjstum.com)

item.title: PEP 809: Stable ABI for the Future
item.description: The Stable ABI as abi3 can no longer be preserved, and requires replacement. abi2026 will be the first replacement, providing resolution of current known incompatibilities, with planned retirement after at least 10 years. The next ABI (for example, abi2031) will have at least five years of overlap with the preceding one.
item.author: Steve Dower (steve.dower@python.org)

item.title: PEP 807: Index support for Trusted Publishing
item.description: This PEP proposes a standard mechanism through which arbitrary Python package indices can support “Trusted Publishing,” a misuse-resistant credential exchange scheme already implemented by the Python Package Index (PyPI).
item.author: William Woodruff (william@yossarian.net)

item.title: PEP 806: Mixed sync/async context managers with precise async marking
item.description: Python allows the with and async with statements to handle multiple context managers in a single statement, so long as they are all respectively synchronous or asynchronous. When mixing synchronous and asynchronous context managers, developers must use deeply nested statements or use risky workarounds such as overuse of AsyncExitStack.
item.author: Zac Hatfield-Dodds (zac@zhd.dev)

item.title: PEP 804: An external dependency registry and name mapping mechanism
item.description: This PEP specifies a name mapping mechanism that allows packaging tools to map external dependency identifiers (as introduced in PEP 725) to their counterparts in other package repositories.
item.author: Pradyun Gedam (pradyunsg@gmail.com), Ralf Gommers (ralf.gommers@gmail.com), Michał Górny (mgorny@quansight.com), Jaime Rodríguez-Guerra (jaime.rogue@gmail.com), Michael Sarahan (msarahan@gmail.com)

item.title: PEP 803: Stable ABI for Free-Threaded Builds
item.description: Version 3.15 of the Stable ABI will be compatible with both free-threaded and GIL-enabled builds. To allow this, the PyObject internal structure and related APIs will be removed from version 3.15 of the Limited API, requiring migration to new API for common tasks like defining modules and most classes.
item.author: Petr Viktorin (encukou@gmail.com)

item.title: PEP 802: Display Syntax for the Empty Set
item.description: We propose a new notation, {/}, to construct and represent the empty set. This is modelled after the corresponding mathematical symbol ‘\emptyset’.
item.author: Adam Turner (adam@python.org)

item.title: PEP 800: Disjoint bases in the type system
item.description: To analyze Python programs precisely, type checkers need to know when two classes can and cannot have a common child class. However, the information necessary to determine this is not currently part of the type system. This PEP adds a new decorator, @typing.disjoint_base, that indicates that a class is a “disjoint base”. Two classes that have distinct, unrelated disjoint bases cannot have a common child class.
item.author: Jelle Zijlstra (jelle.zijlstra@gmail.com)

item.title: PEP 799: A dedicated ``profiling`` package for organizing Python profiling tools
item.description: This PEP proposes the creation of a new standard library module named profiling to organize Python’s built-in profiling tools under a single, coherent namespace.
item.author: Pablo Galindo (pablogsal@python.org), László Kiss Kollár (kiss.kollar.laszlo@gmail.com)

item.title: PEP 798: Unpacking in Comprehensions
item.description: This PEP proposes extending list, set, and dictionary comprehensions, as well as generator expressions, to allow unpacking notation (* and **) at the start of the expression, providing a concise way of combining an arbitrary number of iterables into one list or set or generator, or an arbitrary number of dictionaries into one dictionary, for example:
item.author: Adam Hartz (hz@mit.edu), Erik Demaine (edemaine@mit.edu)
